subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Within Chinese, {{zh-ref|Carr (1990)}} relates it to:
* {{och-l|å’¢|to beat the drum}}, either because drumming was associated with dragons or because some drums were made of crocodilian skins ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).
* Words for â€œfearâ€, e.g. {{och-l|æ„•|startled; terrified}}, {{och-l|å™©|frightening; startling}}.

Outside of Chinese, {{zh-ref|Carr (1990)}} also relates it to:
* {{cog|tai-pro||*Å‹wak|mythical water creature}} (reconstruction from {{zh-ref|Chamberlain, 1977}}), which {{zh-ref|Pittayaporn (2009)}}, reconstructing the root as {{m|tai-pro|*Å‹É¯É™ká´°||crocodile}}, holds to be a loan from Chinese.
* Proto-{{w|Austro-Tai}} {{m|und|*(m)baÅ‹iwak||shark; crocodile}}, posited by {{w|Paul K. Benedict}} and proposed by him to give rise to the Tai word, as well as {{cog|ja|-}} {{ja-r|é°|ã‚ã«|crocodilian; shark}}, {{ja-r|é­š|ã†ãŠ|fish}}.
